content.description:
Up in Smoke is the rather eye catching dihedral to the right of Giggle Drops and gets it's name from the stunning white anti water streaks on the wall, which resemble stylized plumes of smoke rising into the air.

 Start below and just to the right of the upper dihedral on some less than enjoyable stone, to the right of a thick black streak. Thankfully, only a few moves delivers you into good rock and the steeper goods. The start has actually cleaned up a bit and doesn’t feel as scrappy as it used to.

 The first crux comes in the dihedral, and there are two ways of doing it. The original route stays in the dihedral, possibly using a hold just around the right arête, while the path of least resistance strays well left onto Giggle Drops. Both ways of doing it are fun, but only one is the line. The dihedral eventually spills out into a welcomed shake before the next crux. A little toe tapping technical climbing and a few scruffy holds will lead you to some welcomed jugs. One last boulder problem guards the angle break. A great shake at the break let's you eye up the final thought provoking, and exposed climbing to the hanging anchors.
content.protection: 12 Bolts. ClimbTech Mussy Hooks on the anchor provided by the American Safe Climbing Association 4/2018
content.location: Right of Giggle Drops, left of Control Burn

content.description: Techy two bolt start with a solution pocket leads to a break, then weakness (shared start of Burning Point, and Be the Burn). Move up to overhanging bombayesque section where you need to place some semi tricky #.75s and #1s. Keep cranking for your life, and you will eventually pass a few more bolts and jugs to the anchor. A classic trad route. Way more physical, than thoughtful. You aren't going to pussy foot your way up this!
content.protection: Single set, with doubles of # .5 and #1 camalots. Runners.
content.location: Shares start with Be The Burn.

content.description: Scramble up easy terrain to the start of a short dihedral (the dihedral is a fun, short 5.7 sport route). At base of dihedral climb out right past good hold and cruxy slab moves to small bulge. Surmount bulge to fun easier climbing on slight dihedral feature. Finish past small cruxy overhang and then easier climbing in dihedral to anchors.
content.protection: Bolts, 2 bolt anchor with Draco steel biners
content.location: Two routes left of Giggle Drops.

content.description: Beneath the anchors of Flowrider are two fine routes gained by climbing a dead tree leaned up against the wall. Both would be 4 star climbs if the quality of the upper half of the pitches went to the ground. But the tree climb and some chossy rock down low may mar the quality for some.Climb tree. Then climb 11+/12- through three bolts to a good jug. Pull difficult moves (12+) out left on small crimps, then back right to gain the slopey ramp. Here the two routes diverge.Left Route (Imperial Stout): mantle up to a no hands rest in the notch, then climb the elegant black streak (12-) to the chains. The upper bit is really nice climbing on pockets and patina, some of the finest stone at The Peaks.Right route (Unnamed): instead of mantling up to the no hands rest, continue right to a bolt, establish on the prow, and fight your way to a good rest out left (close to Imperial). Step back right onto the prow, and climb up a few more bolts of sustained 12- (including a big move) to the top. The upper bit is reminiscent of Black Swan or Pitbull.**Stickclipping the first two bolts is strongly recommended. Easily done by climbing Flowrider, and hanging draws on the way down. **

Giggle Smoke is a linkup of Giggle Drops and Up in Smoke. If you’re a 5.11 climber looking for something new-ish to do up here, then you’ll appreciate this long and exposed pitch. If you want to hang draws on Up in Smoke, then Giggle Smoke is the route to get you burning.Climb Giggle Drops past the little ledge rest to bolt #7. Clip this with a runner and then traverse right on positive holds and good feet out over open air. Once you join Up in Smoke, you can except ~5.10- climbing that is almost sequential and solid. Plants might be hiding holds.
content.protection: 10 Bolts, 2 bolt hanging chain anchor with ClimbTech mussy hooks provided by the ASCA.
content.location: Starts on Giggle Drops to bolt #7. Finish on the last three bolts of Up in Smoke.

content.description: A great moderate face climb featuring some delicate footwork and a few unexpected handholds through the crux. Starts a little low angle but then becomes sustained through the middle. You get a good rest before the final 25 feet of paddling up a corner to the anchor.
content.protection: 8 bolts, 2 bolt anchor with Draco steel biners

content.description:
Open Project. 

  Insane-o hard climbing on a black and white streaked wall hardly littered with holds. Rumored to be in the .13+ range expect big pulls between some furious micro pockets.   

  Despite serious effort from M.Grecco and others this thing is still a project! Get after it!
content.location: Starts to the right of 'Steeper By The Dozen'

content.description: Excellent and varied route that trends up and right past waves of slabs and steep walls capped with a juggy short roof.
content.location: Start just right of Steeper By The Dozen.

content.description:
Dacite Delight is perhaps the best route here under 5.9, but is a short lived pleasure.

 Scramble up to the first bolt, just left of Latebloomer, then climb dihedral past a little crux.
content.protection: Bolts, 2 bolt anchor with Draco Steel Biners

content.description: Climb up slab to short bulge crux - past fragile holds and thin, sharp crimps. Finish with a romp to chains and huge ledge.
content.location: Just right of Amazon, on the left most short wall of the Left Main Wall.

content.description:
Start as you would for Up In Smoke, clipping the first bolt, then head straight up the bulge above through a slab and to a small ledge (minus 1/2 star). From here climb straight out the steep swoop and finish on the last 4 bolts of Burning Point. Steep and powerful. 3.5 Stars. 

  Grade is my best guess, could be easier or harder.
content.protection: Bolts, 2 bolt anchor with Mad Rock steel biners
content.location: Between Up In Smoke and Burning Point

content.description: Burning Point is the logical, lefthand finish to Be the Burn that climbs the sweeping, steep headwall and has retroactively become the top half of Control Burn. So visually, it now appears as a linkup. This deceptively pumpy route is sure to heat up your forearms and get your heart thumping. I couldn’t call it a jug haul, but there are a lot of generous holds. For the grade, it stands out as one of the better routes in Flag.At the end of the steep, scoopy dihedral of Be the Burn, move sharp left past a little boulder problem involving shallow pockets out left and a slanting rail crimp. This problem leads you to a slippery jug just over the bulge and awesome positioning. Continue up past some pockets out left and big moves over the small roof. A very good shake after the roof will hopefully let you get something back before the little redpoint crux which guards the anchor.
content.protection: Bolts, 2 bolt anchor with Mad Rock steel biners
content.location: Breaks off left of Be The Burn at the very top of the dihedral.

content.description: To the left of Giggle Drops is a large vertical scoop feature. Climb past bolts and moderate terrain, to a scrunchy boulder problem guarding the anchor.
content.protection: Bolts, 2 bolt anchor with Draco steel biners
content.location: In between Latebloomer and Giggle Drops.

content.description: Be the Burn takes on the steep left facing ”dihedral“ to the left of Steeper by the Dozen. The line also shares the same techy start and first three bolts of Steeper by the Dozen. With its unique movement, amazing features, and overall steepness, Be the Burn is one of best of it’s grade for Dacite routes in Flagstaff.Shares start of Steeper by the Dozen. Climb a thin, techy face past a solution pocket to a ledge. Move up the weakness and then left to access the steep, scooped, left facing dihedral. A tricky, palmy stem move guards the entrance to the mondo rail and the steeper climbing. After the dihedral move up and just right through a bouldery sequence to a good shake at a marginal break, (Burning Point breaks off left at the very tippy top of the dihedral).Weave your way up through steep climbing, staying left for the harder line. Grab ahold of the giant glommy rail at the top, and move quickly left to an incut anchor clipping jug. Feels pretty steep for Flag.Back cleaning and runners in the first 1/3 of the route is smart. Clean on top rope.
content.protection: 11 bolts, 2 bolt hanging chain anchor with Draco steel biners
content.location: Shares same techy start and several bolts of Steeper by the Dozen just to the right.

content.description: Climb up through somewhat awkward dihedral (crux). Trend right at end of dihedral and then straight up romping to chains at big ledge.
content.protection: Bolts, 2 bolt anchor with ClimbTech Mussy Hooks provided by the American Safe Climbing Association 4/2018
content.location: Farthest left route on the Main Wall.

content.description: Hard to miss on the far south side of The Main Wall, this may be one of the most beautiful cragging venues in Flagstaff. The base is outlined with a perfect collection of boulders, offering views of town, and highly functional staging areas. The harder lines are steep, long, pumpy, and aesthetic. They almost beg you to climb them. The area also offers enough quality moderates to get the muscle fibers firing or for a mellow cool down.
